title: 113_hr2335
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pay Your Bills or Lose Your Pay Act of 2013". Congress acknowledges the importance of meeting all obligations and maintaining a AAA credit rating for the economic standing of the United States. The statutory debt limit has been increased multiple times in the past, as outlined in the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution. The United States has a public debt limit that can be increased by Congress to pay financial obligations. Moody's has called for the elimination of the debt limit, while Standard and Poor's downgraded the US credit rating. The annual budget resolution specifies the public debt level for each fiscal year. The United States credit rating was downgraded for the first time in history on August 5, 2011, due to political brinksmanship. The 2011 debt limit standoff cost taxpayers $1.3 billion in fiscal year 2011, with a 10-year estimated cost of $18.9 billion according to the Bipartisan Policy Center in January 2013. SEC. 3. Holding salaries of members of Congress in escrow if they fail to meet debt obligations. If the Federal Government reaches the public debt limit, salaries of Members of Congress will be held in escrow until the government can meet its obligations. The public debt limit has been reached, and salaries of Members of Congress will be held in escrow until the debt limit is increased or the end of the One Hundred Thirteenth Congress. Payroll administrators will withhold and remit payments in escrow as required. The payroll administrator of a House of Congress will release any remaining amounts in an escrow account to Members of that House on the last day of the One Hundred Thirteenth Congress. The Secretary of the Treasury will assist the payroll administrators in carrying out this section. The term "Member" in this section includes Delegates or Resident Commissioners to Congress. A payroll administrator is defined as the Chief Administrative Officer of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate, or their designated employees.
